title: .fnt file conversions
content:
Our company owns licenses for the Frutiger family through Monotype. We would like to convert our Frutiger font files to the .fnt file format. The .fnt file format can be used by an engraving machine we've purchased to produce facility signage.

We've come to an agreement with Monotype for a custom license that allows the conversion.

However, Monotype no longer has the capability to complete the conversion to .fnt. We need a separate font company to assist in the file conversions and any necessary font adjustments.

Any suggestions for groups that we might approach for this effort?

I've reached out to some of the more well-known foundries. So far the responses are not good. No one is equipped for .fnt creation.

I understand that the .fnt format is archaic, but it's the only format the engraver will support.

I would appreciate any insight on this topic!
author: jparsley

comments.content: ".fnt" is kind of a generic file extension. Do you have more details? Could it be the Windows 3.0 "bitmapped" type, as used as a rendering cache to quickly display monochrome fonts? (I know -- the latter doesn't really rhyme with 'engraving', but perhaps the machine's manufacturor chose this file format because it's a fairly simple one.)

jparsley, try convert using Fontmonger 1.0.8 (windows):  
 [http://vetusware.com/download/FontMonger%20for%20Windows%201.08/?id=7917](http://web.archive.org/web/20150318000457/http:/vetusware.com/download/FontMonger%20for%20Windows%201.08/?id=7917 "http://vetusware.com/download/FontMonger%20for%20Windows%201.08/?id=7917")

I have no way to test this format, so I can't really take it on as a project. I did find this online though, which might be useful:

[https://www.frictionalgames.com/forum/thread-11128.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150318000457/https:/www.frictionalgames.com/forum/thread-11128.html "https://www.frictionalgames.com/forum/thread-11128.html")
[as Sami told] I made a trip .pfb -\> .fnt -\> .ttf and it looks OK. Important thing - .pfb with no more than 256 letters. The .ttf file with two glyphs with messed orientation, the rest looks good.
No joy, @Theunis – MS uses .fon for these.

Oops. Too long ago :)

Those bitmaps were a welcome resource for my own graphic programming: away with those bland 8x8 characters, here comes Insignia! Not antialiased, though.

Have you guys tried with FontForge? First select  
`  Element -> Bitmap Strikes_Available`  
and choose Win and the point size ; then go to  
`  File -> Generate Fonts...`  
with `No Outline Font` and `Win FNT`. Even if I read a .fon extension before saving, the file saved is `.fnt` and looks ok.
.fnt are scalable fonts aka Nimbus-Q (Digital Typeface Corp., Geo Works in the DOS times) - like Speedo, Intellifonts, Corel's .wfn, etc.
Makes sense, especially as input for an engraving machine!
